captions.text:
Ok, so you remember the setup: 100 people
have had marked dollar bills put randomly

into 100 boxes, and every person, one at a
time, gets to look in fifty of the boxes,

and you all collectively win only if every
single person finds their own bill. $100 dollar

payout to each of you if you win, nothing
if you lose. In the last video I asked whether
or not you should take the bet.
Did you make the right choice?

I mean, clearly, if all 100 of you gamblers
just choose 50 boxes at random when you go

into the room, the likelihood of each of you
finding your bill is one half, so the probability

of ALL of you finding your bills and winning
the whole game is one half times one half

times one half… a hundred times. And one
half to the power of 100 is about 0.0000000000000000000000000000008.

Basically zero. You're more likely to roll
9 one-roll yahtzees in a row - and then pick

the king of hearts at random out of a deck
of cards.

You could do a little better by trying to
correlate which boxes you pick - like, if

there were only two people and two boxes,
they should each pick different boxes, because

if they pick the same box only one of them
can possibly find their own bill, and they'll

automatically lose. But this kind of strategy
only improves your odds a tiny little bit,

and it has less benefit the more people there
are.

However, despite all this, it turns out that
there's a strategy that results in you gamblers

winning over 30% of the time! This strategy
is SO GOOD that you're more likely to win

using it than if just TWO people out of a
hundred picked randomly, since one half times
one half is twenty-five percent.

What we’ve forgotten is that you can obtain
information FROM the boxes themselves, because

the room is exactly the same each time. The
first box will always have the same-numbered

dollar in it, and so will the second box,
the third, the fifty-seventh, etc.

All you have to do is use the dollar in one
box to tell you which box to go to next. This

might not seem like a great advantage, but
it's HUGE.

The trick is to start with the box that corresponds
to your number. Your dollar probably isn't

IN that box, but the bills inside will take
you on a random path through the boxes, a

scavenger hunt where each box tells you where
to go next.

You can think of this as linking up boxes
in chains, connecting them based on the bills
inside.

Any random arrangement of the boxes results
in a different set of chains, some long, some

small. Short chains are ones like "box 30
says go to box 82, box 82 says go to box 5,

5 says go to 30." That's a chain of link 3.
Long chains link up more boxes before circling

back - and the LONGEST possible chain links
up all 100 boxes. But each chain ALWAYS circles
back, since there are finite boxes.

And of course, if you end up back where you
started within 50 boxes, you've won, because

that means the previous box had a dollar bill
that told you to go your starting point, and

you started on your number, so the previous
box's dollar bill was YOURS!

And that's why this strategy is so good - because
when the boxes are randomly arranged, about

30% of the time there will be NO chains connecting
more than 50 boxes, so not only will you win,

but so will everyone else - as long as they’re
following the same strategy!

The magic of this solution isn't that it's
better odds for any single individual to find

their dollar (it isn't) - it's that all of
the successes and failures are forced to happen

together - everyone wins together, everyone
loses together - your fates are linked by

using the numbers inside the boxes to guide
you along invisible chains… towards victory.

"Actutal probabilty is less than 31%, no way you get 100 people to follow 
this all properly."

I was going to say this, but Austin101123 beat me to it.  In any case, 
there is a MUCH MUCH simpler strategy.  The first person checks half of the 
boxes and places them into their corresponding spot, while separating them 
from the remaining boxes.  The second person checks to see if his bill is 
in the boxes already places by first person.  If it is, he moves 49 boxes 
into their corresponding places and then takes the bill from the box he 
first located.  If not, then he moves all 49 boxes. EITHER WAY he is 
guaranteed to find his bill.  So the probability of success is 50% with 
this MUCH simpler strategy.  HOWEVER, this strategy makes one simple 
assumption: That there is enough space in the room to arrange the boxes 
however you want. Another possibility is to simply FLIP over the checked 
boxes. This requires NO extra room but it requires pushing boxes that are 
not checked.﻿

to count number of different permutations of 100 objects which contains 
length 51 circle,
first take 51 objects from 100, which has C(100, 50) ways, then form them a

permute the rest) , at last permute remaining 49, which has 49! ways,

do this from 51 to 100, add the numbers up, we get total number of 
different ways of permutations that contain a longer than 50 circle, call 
it n;

the chance to win is 1 - n/100! which is, calculated using python,

comments.text:
This had me confused for a good while before I finally figured it out.  I 
watched and re-watched the video at least 15 times.  Looking at the 
comments, there are many others who are equally as confused as I was.  
Hopefully this helps clear things up.

1.  This is part TWO of a two video series.  This video only explains the 
answer, and does not specify all the rules to the game.  At the beginning 
of this video, there is a box linking to the original video.  That video 
should clear up all the rules to the game.
2.  The "31 %" is NOT the odds of any single person finding their bill.  
Instead, it is the odds of there being no "chain" greater than 50.  THIS IS 
IMPORTANT since each participant only has 50 tries to find their bill.
3.  Every participant belongs to one of these "chains". 
4.  According to this strategy, everyone STARTS at the box that corresponds 
to their number.  So if someone is looking for a bill with a 5 on it, they 
start at the 5th box.  By doing so, they are GUARANTEED to be in the 
correct "chain".  This is explained at 2:30. 

If there is a 31% chance of there being NO chain greater than 50 boxes and 
every participant BELONGS to a chain, then the group as a whole has a 31% 
chance of winning so long as they start at the correct box and follow the 
strategy.  Hope this helps!﻿

comments.text:
+Life Happens If the risk is $1, and the reward is $100, then you only need 
the chance of winning to be greater than 1% to make a profit. If you're 
allowed to play the game many times, and the chance of winning is 2%, then 
you'll on average spend only $50 for every $100 you win.

If you're only allowed to play the game once though, that's when you might 
need to consider whether you care about losing that $1. It's only $1 
though, so chances are, you won't miss it. If the reward outweighs the 
risk, then go for it.

Of course, real gambling institutions usually rig the games so that the 
risk is ever so slightly higher than the reward, so that it still feels 
like you have a fair chance, but in the long run the house will always come 
out on top. If they were running a game like this, and found out there was 
a way to reliably beat it, they would probably stop running the game.

comments.author: JeevS GOne

comments.text:
for my simulation modeling class final project, we did something very 
similar to this. we had to figure out how shipping packages can be 
optimized. You assign all destinations a random number, and you start at a 
destination mapped to a number. Every time a successful delivery is made, 
it generates another number which can be used for the next delivery 
(through the corresponding number). This generated number continues a chain 
that is actually quite optimal.

Believe it or not, 58% of the time, it's actually faster this way to 
deliver packages to houses than simply going to the next nearest 
destination. ﻿
